Circles of Trust

About CWS


CWS gives you an easy way to store any data safely encrypted.

Data is never persisted unencrypted and only minimal necessary metadata is stored.

Support for circles of trust allows to share encrypted data amongst a group of people.

We have close to 100% test coverage.


Lightweight Backend

CWS, Cryptographic Web Store or Crypto Store - is designed to be used as a backend component in other systems, added between existing persistence layer and the database. It uses a combination of standard cryptographic operations to ensure that the stored data is saved enrypted in a way, so only those who should have access to it, can access it.

Solid Java - Minimal Dependencies

Technically, CWS is written in Java 8 / Java EE 7. It only relies on the SLF4J logging framework and nothing else. This way, it will deploy in any Java EE 7+ compliant Containers or Java EE7+ Compliant Cloud and work. The database layer is written using JPA, so the underlying database can be changed to whichever is desired. The initially supported databases include H2, HyperSQL & PostgreSQL. Support for other databases can be made easily.

Communication

Communication is achieved via a public API, which allows both REST (scheduled for version 0.8) and SOAP based WebService requests. This will give a high degree of flexibility for anyone to integrate it into their system.

Circles of Trust

The CWS focuses on Circles of Trust, where Members of a Circle will have varying level of access to the Data belonging to the Circle. This is achieved by a combination of Symmetric and Asymmetric Encryption, guaranteeing that only Members with Access can view Data. Private & Symmetric Keys are stored encrypted, as is the Data Objects given. It should be noted, that the Data Objects stored can be anything, CWS is expectiny an array of bytes as source and will return an array of bytes, what those bytes actually contain is irrelevant for CWS - but CWS does support storing the encrypted data with a type, which can be used by the systems using it, to ensure that all Data Objects can be correctly read out.



Documentation


Who is this for

Although security is the key part of using CWS - it is not possible to achieve a level of security which will be demanded from many corporations, organizations or governments. To obtain such a degree of security, the best advice is to not use hosting or cloud services. As they will inherently be your achilles heel.

CWS is aiming at improving security for others, who neither can nor will pay for additional security by either hosting data themselves or use other means of improved tools. The goal is not to achieve perfect security but to make life harder for hackers to read out data.

If this is what is your goal, then CWS may be a tool which use can find useful in your chain.

Disclaimer

As stated above, CWS neither can nor will aim at perfect security. That said, the work with developing CWS has been with the primary focus on improving backend security, by ensuring that what is stored is all encrypted.

Generally, there are 3 areas where security will come up short:

  • Hosting or Cloud Provider
    If the hosting provider is not taking their customers data security seriously, either by not patching their software or protecting their services using firewalls. Then, CWS cannot give you a guarentee that your data is secure. As CWS requires that the underlying software to run Java & Java EE must be properly updated.
  • Network Communication
    CWS uses WebServices (REST / SOAP) for all requests. this means that the communication must be properly secured with SSL. If not, then all data send or received may be compromised, as it can be sniffed over the net. As SSL is added to the containers, it is not part of CWS, and as with patches & firewalls, CWS relies on a proper setup.
  • Data Processing
    During the processing of data, both the data and the keys will appear in readable form in the memory of the host. It is possible for someone with access to the hosts to make memory dumps, and this way obtain the information.

Of these shortcomings, the last sounds like the worst, but as CWS is suppose to be added between your Persistence Logic & Database, the data is already present in other components and reading it out from those may be simpler. Put in short, the aim is not to focus on security of the processing, but storing - hence the name Crypto Store.


Release Plan

  • 0.6 - Released November 17, 2017.
    First public beta, it is feature complete and the data model is final. The API may still alter slight to increase consistency.
  • 0.7 - Scheduled for December, 2017.
    Documentation Release, this includes documentation of the finalized API, and documentation for installing and running CWS under various Java EE 7 compliant Application Servers as well as Cloud Hosts.
  • 0.8 - Scheduled for December, 2017.
    REST Support, support for REST has been pending the completion of the API.
  • 0.9 - Scheduled for December, 2017.
    External review. Code Quality.
  • 1.0 - Scheduled for December 31, 2017
    First public release


Download CWS 0.6


The first beta-grade version of CWS is ready. It is tested under WildFly 11 using PostgreSQL. The current version is dubbed 0.6, as it reflects the completed milestones in GitHub.

We encourage you to test it, any feedback will be welcome, as it will only help improve CWS in preparation of the release of the final 1.0 version.
